gurmukhi: pRwqkwl BXo AMDkwr imt gXo kRoD sUrin ko BXo rQ swij kY sBY cly ] ieqY biRjrwie bldyv jU bulwie mn mhwN suKu pwie jdubIr sMg lY Bly ]
transliteration: Praatkaal Bhayo Andhkaar Mit Gado Krodh Sooran(i) Ko Bhayo Rath Saaj(i) Kai Sabhai Chale|| Itai Brijraae Baldev Joo Bulaae Man Mahaan Soukh(u) Paae Jadoubeer San Lai Bhale||
translation: The darkness (of night) ended with day-dawned, the warriors, in anger, and bedecking their chariots, started (for war); on this side, the Lord of Braja, in a state of supreme bliss in his mind, and calling Balram went (for war);

gurmukhi: auqY fr fwr kY hiQXwrn sMBwr kY su Awey hY hkwr kY At`l Bt nw tly ] sXMdn Dvwie sMK duMdB bjwie dÍY qurMgin ky Bwie dl Awpis ibKY rly ]1267]
transliteration: Outai Dar Daar Kai Hathiyaaran Sanbhaar Kai Su Aae Su Aae Hai Hakaar Kai Atall Bhat Naa Tale|| Syaandan Dhavaae Sankh Doundabh Bajaae Dvai Turanad(i) Ke Bhaae Dal Aapas(i) Bikhai Rale||1267||
translation: On that side also, forsaking fear and holding their weapons, the warriors moved forward shouting loudly; driving their chariots, blowing their conches and beating small drums and riding int heir horses, both the armies fell upon each other.1267.

gurmukhi: sXMdn pY hir soiBXY Aimq qyj kI Kwn ] kumdn jwnXo cMdRmw kMjn mwno Bwn ]1268]
transliteration: Syaandan Pai Har(i) Sobhiya Amit Tej Kikhaan|| Koumdan Jaanyo Channdramaa Kanjan Maano Bhaan||1268||
translation: Krishna, sitting in his chariots looked splendid like the mine of unlimited light; the the asphodels considered him as moon and the lotus flowers considered him as sun.1268.

gurmukhi: Gn jwn kY mor nicE bn mwNJ ckor lKXo sis ky sm hY ] mn kwmn kwm srUp BXo pRB dwsin jwnXo nroqm hY ]
transliteration: Ghan Jaan Kai Mor Nachio Ban Maanjh Chakor Lakhyo Sas(i) Ke Sam Hai|| Man Kaamanndkaam Saroop Bhayo Prabh Daasan(i) Jaanyo Darotam Hai||
translation: The peacocks, considering him as cloud, began to dance, partridges considered him as moon and danced in the forest; the women thought that he was the god of love and the servant-maids considered him as a superb human;

gurmukhi: br joign jwn jugISr eISr rogn mwnXo sdw Cm hY ] hir bwln bwlk rUp lKXo ijK du`jn jwnXo mhw jm hY ]1269]
transliteration: Bar Jogin Jaan Jougeeshar Eeshar Rogad Maanyo Sadaa Chham Hai Har(i) Baalan Baalak Roop Lakhyo Jiya Dujjan Jaanyo Mahaa Jam Hai||1269||
translation: The Yogis thought that he was a Supreme Yogi and the ailments thought that he was the remedy; the children considered him as child and the wicked people saw him as death.1269.

gurmukhi: ckvwn idnyS gjwn gnyS gnwn mhyS mhwqm hY ] mGvw DrnI hir ijau hirnI aupmw brnI n kCU sRm hY ]
transliteration: Chakvaan Dinesh Gadaan Gadesh Gadaan Mahesh Mahaatam Hai|| Maghvaa Dharnidar(i) Jio Harinioupm Barnina Kachhodh Sram Hai||
translation: The ducks considered him as the sun, the elephants as Ganesh and the Ganas as Shiva; he seemed to be like Indra, earth and Vishnu, but he also looked like an innocent doe;

gurmukhi: miRg jUQn nwd srUp BXo ijnky n ibbwd iqnY dm hY ] inj mIqn mIq hÍY cIq bsXo hir S`qRin jwnXo mhwN jm hY ]1270]
transliteration: Mrig Jeethan Naad Saroop Bhayo Jinke Na Bibaad Tinai Dam Hai|| Nij Meetan Meet Hvai Cheet Basyo Har(i) Shattran(i) Jaanyo Mahaan Jam Hai||1270||
translation: For the deer, he was like the horn and for the men sans strifes, he was like life-breath; for the friends, he was like a friend abiding in mind and for the enemies, he looked like Yama.1270.

gurmukhi: dÍY sYnw iekTI BeI Aiq mn kop bFwie ] ju`D krq hY bIr br rn duMdBI bjwie ]1271]
transliteration: Dvai Sainaa Ikathibhaiat(i) Man Kop Badhaae|| Juddh Karat Hai Beer Kar Ran Doundabhibajaae||1271||
translation: The armies of both the sides, in great anger, gathered together and the warriors playing upon their trumpets etc. began to wage war.1271.

gurmukhi: DUm Dujw mn Daur Drw Dr isMG sBY rn kop kY Awey ] lY krvwrn Fwl krwl hÍY SMk qjI hir swmuih Dwey ]
transliteration: Dhoom Dhujaa Man Dhaur Dharaa Dhar Singh Sabhai Ran Kop Kai Aae|| Lai Karvaaran Dhaal Karaal Hvai Shank Tajihar(i) Saamuh(i) Dhaae||
translation: The kings namely Dhum, Dhvaja, Man, Dhaval And Dharadhar Singh, in great fury, reached the battlefield; they ran before Krishna, forsaking all their illusions, taking their shields and swords in their hands;
